title-group.article-title: Nanostructure cobalt oxide reinforced conductive and magnetic polyaniline nanocomposites

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Physics, RTM Nagpur University, India
2Department of Physics, Institute of Science, India
3Department of Physics, B. D. College of Engineering, Sevagram, Wardha, Nagpur University, Nagpur, India

author-notes.corresp: Subhash Kondawar, Department of Physics, RTM Nagpur University, Nagpur 440033, India. Email: sbkondawar@yahoo.co.in

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Nanocrystalline cobalt oxide (Co3O4) was synthesized by sol–gel method using cobalt chloride as precursor. Conducting polyaniline-cobalt oxide (PANI/Co3O4) nanocomposites were synthesized by in situ polymerization of aniline (monomer) in the presence of as-synthesized nanocrystalline Co3O4. The synthesized nanocomposites were characterized by XRD, FTIR, UV-VIS and TEM analysis. TEM images show that PANI has been coated on nanocrystalline Co3O4, which confirms the formation of nanocomposites. XRD pattern show that nanocrystalline Co3O4 embedded into polycrystalline PANI to form crystalline nanocomposites. Fourier transform infrared and ultraviolet visible spectroscopy show that cobalt oxide nanoparticles get electrostatically bound to the specific sites of polyaniline. PANI/Co3O4 nanocomposites show semiconducting behavior as that of conducting polyaniline. In this article, the influence of filler concentration on the transport parameters and magnetic properties of polyaniline nanocomposites has been investigated.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The nanocomposites with an organized structure usually provide a new functional hybrid, with synergistic properties over their single component counterparts, which have attracted considerable attention for their potential applications.1 Polymer nanocomposites are an important class of polymers, which have wide applications in a number of different industrial sectors and thus organic/inorganic nanocomposite materials have been extensively studied in the last few decades. Conducting polymer nanocomposites possess the advantages of both low dimensional systems (nanostructure filler) and organic conductors (conducting polymer). The nanostructure filler plays the major role in strengthening the properties of the nanocomposites. Uniform dispersion of these nanoscopically sized filler particles produces ultra large interfacial area per volume between the nano-size filler and the host polymer. Thus, nanostructure filler into polymer matrix provide opportunities to enhance the properties associated with conventional composite materials.2 The conducting polyaniline (PANI) is one of the promising conducting polymers due to its high conductivity, ease of preparation, good environmental stability and large variety of applications, which make this polymer suitable as a matrix for preparation of conducting polymer nanocomposites.3,4 Therefore, there has been increasing interest of the researchers for the preparation of nanocomposites based on PANI. The literature review on conducting polymer nanocomposites shows that PANI has been successfully utilized for the preparation of nanocomposites such as PANI-TiO2,5–7 PANI-Fe3O4,8–10 PANI-NiO,11,12 PANI-ZnO,13,14 PANI-CNT,15–18 graphite-polyaniline (G-PANI),19 etc. When nanostructure filler particles are magnetic in polymer matrix, then such nanocomposites show enhanced magnetic as well as transport properties of the polymer. Magnetic materials such as cobalt oxide (Co3O4) have attracted great interest in view of their technological and fundamental scientific importance.20–23 Co3O4 belongs to the normal spinel structure of AB2O4 type, in which Co2+ ions occupy the tetrahedral 8a sites and Co3+ ions occupy the octahedral 16d sites in the crystal lattice. In bulk crystalline form Co3O4 exhibits antiferromagnetism with Neel temperature of about 40 K, whereas nanosized Co3O4 shows weak ferromagnetism or superparamagnetic properties.24 Nanocrystalline Co3O4 was found to have interesting magnetic, optical field emission and electrochemical properties which are attractive in device applications. Thus, tremendous efforts have been directed in recent years to the synthesis and investigation of properties of Co3O4 nanostructures. Various strategies have been developed to synthesize Co3O4 nanoparticles such as microwave irradiation, ultrasonic assisted method, hydrothermal synthesis, solvothermal, sol–gel, liquid assisted methodology, etc. For producing PANI as a magnetic semiconductor, Hatamie et al.25 reported the cobalt nanoparticles doped PANI. Wang et al.26 reported the thermal analysis of PANI-Co3O4 nanocomposites, wherein fine grade powder of average particle size 80 nm of cobalt oxide was used as purchased and simply mixed with aniline during polymerization. Patil et al.27 reported transport properties and dielectric behavior of PANI-Co3O4 nanocomposites, in which also cobalt oxide was used as purchased and simply mixed with aniline during polymerization. Shambharkar et al.24 reported the synthesis of Co3O4 and PANI-Co3O4 nanocomposites, wherein Co3O4 and PANI-Co3O4 nanocomposites are paramagnetic. To investigate the transport properties along with the ferromagnetic behavior of PANI-Co3O4 nanocomposites, we have synthesized nanocrystalline Co3O4 by a simple sol–gel approach of co-precipitation method and well dispersed by ultrasonication before polymerization to observe the influence of as-synthesized nanocrystalline cobalt oxide as filler on PANI composites. In the study of transport properties, first time we have reported the transport parameters such as charge localization length (α−1), most probable hopping distance (R) and charge hopping energy (w) of PANI-Co3O4 nanocomposites. In the magnetic study also, an important assessment of the quality of the magnetic materials, the squareness ratio (SQR = Mr/Ms) of PANI-Co3O4 nanocomposites has been discussed.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: Aniline (99%) and cobalt chloride (99%) were purchased from Merck. Ammonium persulphate (APS) (99%) was purchased from Qualigens Fine Chemicals. Other supplement chemicals were of AR grade and used as received except aniline which was distilled prior to use.

X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern was obtained using Philips PW1710 automatic X-ray diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.5404 Å) and scanning speed of 10° min−1. FTIR spectra were performed on Shimatzu FTIR-8101A Spectrophotometer in the wavelength range of 400–4000 cm−1. Transmission electron microscopy images were obtained using PHILIPS-CM200 TEM with resolution 2.4 Å. The optical absorption spectra were carried out using UV-1800 double beam UV-VIS spectrophotometer. The electrical conductivity was determined by four probe resistivity technique. The pellets were prepared with the help of hydraulic press (Kimaya Engineers, India) by applying a pressure of 5 tons. The magnetization measurements were carried out using vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM) model Oxford Maglab 14T.

sec.title: Synthesis of Co3O4 nanoparticles
sec.p: Cobalt oxide (Co3O4) nanoparticles were prepared by the simple approach of sol–gel process28 in which requisite amount of cobalt chloride (precursor) was added to starch solution and then stirring the solution for 30 min. Prepared solution was hydrolyzed by NaOH under constant stirring at room temperature for 2 h. The solution was kept overnight and then filtered using membrane filtration assembly, washed using deionized water and ethanol to remove the impurities and then dried at 80°C in hot air oven. Dried sample was treated at different temperatures in order to maintain the stability of compound. The color of the sample was changed from faint green at 100°C to black at 750°C. This cobalt oxide was used to prepare PANI/Co3O4 nanocomposites.

sec.title: Synthesis of PANI/Co3O4 nanocomposites
sec.p:
The PANI/Co3O4 nanocomposite was prepared by an in situ chemical oxidation polymerization of aniline using APS as an oxidant in presence of Co3O4 nanoparticles at room temperature in air.24 Aniline (0.1 M) and APS (0.1 M) were dissolved separately in1 M H2SO4 solution and stirred for 1 h. As-synthesized Co3O4 nanoparticles were suspended separately in 1 M H2SO4 solution and sonicated for 1 h to reduce aggregation of Co3O4 nanoparticles. 100 mL aniline solution and 10 mL Co3O4 suspension were mixed and further sonicated for 30 min. 100 mL APS solution was then slowly added dropwise to well-dispersed suspension mixture with a continuous stirring. After 3 h, a good degree of polymerization was achieved. The solution was left in undisturbed position for overnight to complete the chemical reaction. The precipitate produced in the reaction was removed by filtration, washed repeatedly with 1 M H2SO4 and dried under vacuum for 24 h. The composite powder thus obtained was conductive emeraldine salt (ES) form of PANI/Co3O4. The synthesis of PANI/Co3O4 nanocomposite is summarized in the form of flow chart as shown in Scheme 1. The different contents PANI/Co3O4 nanocomposites were synthesized using 5, 10, 15, 20 wt% of Co3O4 with respect to aniline monomer. The nanocomposites were abbreviated as PC-5, PC-10, PC-15 and PC-20, respectively for PANI/Co3O4 (5%), PANI/Co3O4 (10%), PANI/Co3O4 (15%) and PANI/Co3O4 (20%). Scheme 1.
Flow chart for synthesis of PANI-Co3O4 nanocomposites.

sec.title: IR analysis
sec.p:
FTIR spectra of Co3O4, PANI and PANI/Co3O4 nanocomposites are shown in Figure 1. Two bands at 668 cm−1 and 577 cm−1 in the spectra of Co3O4 confirm the spinel structure of Co3O4. The peak at 668 cm−1 and 577 cm−1 could be assigned to M–O stretching in which M is Co2+ tetrahedral coordinated and Co3+ octahedral coordinated, respectively.29 The main characteristic peaks at 1489 and 1562 cm−1 could be assigned to C–C stretching of the benzenoid and quinoid rings of PANI, respectively. These results indicate that the pure PANI is highly doped and exists in conducting emeraldine salt form. The peaks at 1299 cm−1 and 1122 cm−1 could be assigned to C–N stretching of secondary amine and plane bending vibration of C–H of pure PANI, respectively. FTIR spectra of PANI/Co3O4 nanocomposites are almost identical to that of the pure PANI. The bands observed in pure Co3O4 gets shifted towards smaller wave numbers as the weight percentage of the filler increases from 5% to 20% in the PANI. The bands at 577 and 668 cm−1 in pure Co3O4 have been observed at 547 and 641 cm−1 in 20% composites. Thus overall all bands shift slightly towards red, and the intensity ratio of quinonoid to benzenoid band has also changed. This is due to the fact that there is kind of weak Vander Waals force of attraction between polymer chain and Co3O4. These results indicate the formation of polymer nanocomposites due to some interactions exist between PANI and Co3O4. Figure 1.
FTIR spectra of PANI/Co3O4 nanocomposites.

sec.title: XRD analysis
sec.p:
Figure 2 shows typical XRD patterns of Co3O4, PANI and PANI/Co3O4 nanocomposites. XRD pattern of as-synthesized Co3O4 reveals that XRD peaks can be indexed as those of cubic structure with a = 8.06 Å, in accordance with the JCPDS file (80-1537) of Co3O4. Crystallite size of the Co3O4 was determined using Scherer’s formula and found to be 35 nm which closely agreement with that determined by Shambharkar et al.24 Co3O4 nanoparticles with cubic structure showed four broad peaks at about 31.67°, 37.26°, 59.75° and 65.56° for its nanostructure. It reveals that Co3O4 synthesized by the sol–gel method is nanocrystalline. The pure PANI exhibits two broad peaks at 2θ angles around 20.4° and 26.1°, which indicate PANI is polycrystalline. These peaks may be assigned to the scattering from PANI chains at interplanar spacing. When Co3O4 nanoparticles are incorporated into PANI, the broad diffraction peaks of the PANI disappear gradually, which is possibly because the nanoparticles have acted as ‘impurities’ to hamper the growth of the PANI ‘crystallites’. Most of the peaks of nanocomposites are the reflections of the Co3O4 nanoparticles indicating the PANI coating on cobalt oxide as seen in TEM images of PANI- Co3O4 nanocomposite (PC-15). Figure 2.
XRD patterns of PANI/Co3O4 nanocomposites.

sec.title: UV-VIS analysis
sec.p:
UV-visible spectra of PANI/Co3O4 nanocomposites in DMF solvent are shown in Figure 3. There are two absorption bands in the electronic spectra of PANI/Co3O4 nanocomposites as that of PANI. The band around 330 nm is assigned to π–π* transition (band gap) and the band around 660 nm is due to inter band charge transfer associated with the excitation of benzenoid to quinoid moieties (formation of an exciton – bipolaronic band) in PANI.30,31 After combining PANI with other nanocomponents to form nanocomposites, bipolaronic band is usually shifted to lower wavelength, revealing interactions between nanocomponents and the quinoid rings of PANI. As the content of Co3O4 in PANI matrix was increased from 0 to 20 wt%, bipolaronic band shifts significantly from 660 nm to 590 nm indicating strong interactions between the quinoid ring of PANI and Co3O4. This hypsochromic or blue shift indicates an increase in band gap brought about by an increase in the torsion angle between adjacent rings causes the change in delocalization of electrons in PANI structure (i.e. variation in energy gap between HOMO and LUMO) with incorporation of cobalt oxide nanoparticles in PANI. The shift in bipolaronic band towards shorter wavelength side with the increase in wt% of the Co3O4 in PANI matrix may be due to increased charge carrier scattering between PANI and Co3O4.32 Figure 3.
UV-VIS spectra of PANI/Co3O4 nanocomposites.

sec.title: TEM analysis
sec.p:
Figure 4(a) and (b) show TEM images of Co3O4 nanoparticles and PANI-Co3O4 (15%) nanocomposites (PC-15), respectively. It reveals that Co3O4 nanoparticles were mostly spherical with diameter less than 50 nm. PANI-Co3O4 (15%) nanocomposite exhibits similar shape as that of Co3O4 nanoparticles with some aggregation as a result of aniline polymerization and growth encircled the Co3O4 nanoparticles which are uniformly dispersed within the polymer matrix. Figure 4.
(a) TEM image of Co3O4; (b) TEM image of PANI-Co3O4 (15%) nanocomposites.

sec.title: Electrical conductivity
sec.p:
Figure 5 shows the electrical conductivity of PANI-Co3O4 nanocomposites at different temperature. The increase in conductivity of PANI-Co3O4 nanocomposites with the increase in temperature is the characteristics of thermal activated behavior following quasi-1D the variable range hopping conductivity model. Generally, incorporating an insulating component into conducting polymer will decrease the electrical conductivity because of the partial blockage of conductive path by the insulating component. On the other hand, incorporating another nanocomponent with high electrical conductivity into conducting polymers may enhance the conductivity of nanocomposites.32 The electrical conductivity of PANI-Co3O4 nanocomposites is slightly lower than that of pure PANI but much higher than that of Co3O4. The decrease in the conductivity by addition of Co3O4 may be due to the blocking of charge carriers which do not have sufficient energy to hop between favorable sites. The decrease of the composite conductivity is attributed to the increased charge carrier scattering between doped PANI and Co3O4. As the Co3O4 particles embedded in the PANI matrix interrupted the doping process, interactions between Co3O4 and PANI increased the localization of charge carriers, and thus decreased the conductivity of the composites. A similar decrease in electrical conductivity was also observed in various kinds of conducting polymer nanocomposites.33–35 With increase of Co3O4 content in PANI matrix, the decrease in electrical conductivity was observed due to increase in blockage for the charge carriers. The room temperature conductivity of the nanocomposites along with transport parameters are reported in Table 1. Figure 5.
Electrical conductivity of PANI-Co3O4 nanocomposites.
Table 1.
Transport parameters of PANI and PANI/Co3O4 nanocomposites
Polymers σ (S/m) at 303 K To (K) α−1 (nm) R (nm) w (eV)
PANI 40.4 14085 0.862 2.15 0.303
PC-5 37.6 18738 0.646 1.61 0.404
PC-10 36.5 20349 0.595 1.48 0.438
PC-15 35.0 22054 0.549 1.37 0.475
PC-20 28.5 22945 0.528 1.32 0.496

To find transport parameters of the polymer nanocomposites from the data of electrical conductivity, Ziller equation has been used, which describes the interchain conductivity where only the neighbor variable range hoping (VRH) of charge is considered. σ(T)=σ(o).e(ToT)1/2

The plot of log σ(T) versus T−1/2 was found to be linear for pure PANI and PANI—Co3O4 nanocomposites, hence To was determined from the slope of the line. ‘To’ the characteristic temperature, can be used to calculate the transport parameters such as charge localization length (α−1), most probable hopping distance (R) and charge hopping energy (w) using the following relations, To=8αN(EF)ZkR=(ToT)1/2(α-14)w=ZkTo16

In these relations, Z is the number of nearest neighboring chains (∼4), k is Boltzmann constant and N(EF) is the density of states per electron volt (2-ring unit suggested for polyaniline).36 Although nanocomposites have room temperature (303 K) conductivity less as compared to pure PANI but conductivity of nanocomposites is due the extended chain length of polyaniline where polarons possess sufficient energy to hop between favorable sites. The electrical conductivity of PANI/Co3O4 nanocomposites shows semiconducting behavior as that of conducting polyaniline with filler concentration-dependant variation of transport parameters. From Table 1, it is seen that the transport parameters of PANI/Co3O4 nanocomposites are depending on the concentration of the filler. As the concentration of the filler in PANI matrix increases, the charge localization length and most probable hoping distance decreases whereas hoping energy and the characteristic temperature increases which may be due to increase of blockage or decrease of path way for the carriers.

sec.title: Magnetic behavior
sec.p:
Figure 6 shows a typical hysteresis loop obtained at room temperature for PANI/Co3O4 nanocomposites. Saturation magnetization (Ms) for cobalt oxide was found to be 11.3 × 10−7 Wb-m/kg with coercive field (Hc) 4.01 × 10−2 T and the remanent magnetization (Mr) at 107.8 × 10−9 Wb-m/kg indicating that pure Co3O4 is ferromagnetic in nature, as compared to paramagnetic reported.24 The squareness ratio (SQR = Mr/Ms) is an important assessment of the quality of the magnetic materials. The SQR for the pure Co3O4 was found to be 94.70 × 10−3 indicating that the pure Co3O4 do not have the properties of a recording medium.37 Ms and Mr for PANI were found to be 3.14 × 10−7 Wb-m/kg and 7.15 × 10−9 Wb-m/kg without the hysteresis loop indicating paramagnetic as shown in inset. Figure 6.
Magnetic behavior of the PANI-Co3O4 nanocomposites.

PANI/Co3O4 nanocomposites show ferromagnetic with hysteresis loop area depending on concentration of Co3O4 in PANI matrix. The SQR along with Ms, Mr and Hc for nanocomposites are reported in Table 2, which shows that nanocomposites do not have the properties of a recording medium as like pure Co3O4 but are good conductors as compared to Co3O4. Such materials are finding applications as soft magnetic materials in constructing transformers and cathode materials in batteries. Table 2.
Magnetic parameters of Co3O4, PANI and PANI/Co3O4 nanocomposites
Materials Ms (Wb-m/kg) Mr (Wb-m/kg) Hc (T) SQR
Co3O4 11.3 × 10−7 107.8 × 10−9 4.01 × 10−2 95.5 × 10−3
PANI 3.14 × 10−7 7.15 × 10−9 – 22.8 × 10−3
PC-5 4.27 × 10−7 38.3 × 10−9 2.25 × 10−2 89.7 × 10−3
PC-10 5.90 × 10−7 53.6 × 10−9 2.74 × 10−2 90.8 × 10−3
PC-15 6.53 × 10−7 65.1 × 10−9 3.09 × 10−2 99.8 × 10−3
PC-20 7.20 × 10−7 71.8 × 10−9 3.40 × 10−2 98.6 × 10−3

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: PANI/Co3O4 nanocomposites have been successfully prepared by incorporating Co3O4 nanoparticles into PANI matrix. The incorporation of Co3O4 into PANI matrix affects the electrical conductivity and magnetic properties of nanocomposites. It is observed that the electrical and magnetic properties of the composite depend on concentration of Co3O4 in the composite. FTIR spectra, UV-VIS spectra, XRD patterns and TEM images of PANI/Co3O4 nanocomposites indicate the interactions exist between PANI and nanocrystalline Co3O4. PANI/Co3O4 nanocomposites show ferromagnetic as that of Co3O4 but high electrical conductivity forming conductive magnetic materials may be useful for transformer and batteries.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
